title: Will there be a new king of Saudi Arabia before 1 October 2018?
possible_answers: Yes, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman
preds: No reason for now. MBS wants to show an image of legitimacy.
Problems with the king's health remain the most likely culprit in upsetting my forecast.

I estimate the odds of: (1) King Salman's death, or 
(2) King Salman abdicating the throne,  at substantially greater than 1 to 100 over the next 14 days.
Timewise the chance of dying from natural causes is less than 0.5%. I would give decimal chances if it was possible.

There is now less than 3 months before this question ends. The average age of death of the last 3 Kings was 84. The current king is not in very good health, but the previous 3 kings were also not in good health for their last years. So I would give the current king a 50% chance of reaching 84, which he would reach in 2 years. So a very rough assumption is that there is about a 2% chance each month that the current king will die. So with less than three months to go I calculate there is about a 5% chance of new king and a 90% chance the new king will MBS.

The sudden power grab in Saudi Arabia by Mohammed bin Salam ignored the historical power-sharing arrangement dispersed throughout the ruling family and the different branches to maintain political checks and balances and stability in the kingdom. Mohammed bin Salam, after his heady rise to power, may be seeing a backlash from the rest of the disenfranchised, robbed and tortured Royal Family. This consolidation of power is not the "style" of the Saudis.
    MBS has been keeping a very low profile recently. Then there was the perplexing arrest of the 11 female activists. It could be perhaps that MBS was never 100% successful in bringing the religious conservatives,  the Council of Senior Scholars, heel. It is possible they are asserting their disapproval and moreover may very well be supporting a power-sharing arrangement with a different branch of the Royal Family that will not include the idea of MBS ruling for the next 50 years. Perhaps Salam will be replaced by another son of Abdulaziz in keeping with the traditional lines of succession for Saudi kings.
   October might be an appropriate amount of time for this to come to fruition.  I would suspect that there would be more movement towards the end of Ramadan or shortly thereafter.

Started with a judgement of 50/50 based on King Salman staying alive. Scaling back each month as we get closer to 01 October.

I can't find any news about any other contender to the crown besides MBS. But there are many people in the Saudi family, so let's give "someone else" 1%. From browsing the news, it looks like MBS does as he pleases in KSA, and maybe even rules over his father. (E.g. is rumored to have placed his mother under house arrest.) This makes sense from a game-theoretic perspective: everyone in KSA knows he'll be absolute monarch in the next 10 years, so why would they disobey/antagonize him unless directly and seriously threatened by the current king? Following that reasoning, MBS wouldn't seem to have a strong motive to oust/retire his father. Currently he enjoys most of the benefits of power, with fewer obligations. (I imagine the king has to attend events, give speeches, etc.) The current king is 82. Actuarial tables give ~5% chance of death for an 82-year old man. Since the king of KSA is one of the richest men on Earth, we can knock that down to 3%, say. And we only have 6 months to go, so call it 2% chance of him dying before Q deadline. Then again he is rumored to have Alzheimer's (though I can't find confirmation) so double that, to 4%. So if we assume the current king will only be replaced by dying --- as has historically been the case with 5 out of 7 kings, including the last 3, since 1975 --- the odds of "no" should be 95%, and MBS 4%. And I think it would look bad for MBS to oust/retire him so quickly after being named Crown Prince. Still, this is all unfamiliar enough to me that I'll double my uncertainty: 2% someone else, 8% MBS.
Started with a judgement of 50/50 based on King Salman staying alive. Scaling back each month as we get closer to 01 October.

There is little to be gained by the Crown Prince from this move and no realistic threat to his succession.  Healthwise, the King seems good for another few years at least.  But then again he is in his eighties and the Crown Prince has been known to do the unexpected.

Recent successes in negotiations with Russia (Aramco, opec agreement), and large defense purchase slightly increase the chance of abdication.

The current king has been ruling since 2015. Therefore i think it is unlikey that he will abandon his post in favor of his son before oct. '18. However if he faces severe health problems or even death this could obv. accelerate the line of succession.
For someone else to become king there must occur a sudden change of power, which i consider unlikely before oct

The Crown Prince is effectively in charge and the Saudis haveva number of very serious regional problems in their plate. They will do their best to broadcast stability and project an image as the dominant player in the Middle East. The King shall continue to sit in the throne.
Upgrade +2 after discussions with Saudi expert relaying that MBS is really shaking things up vs the traditionalists. If there is a power struggle, he may be crowned before the king dies.

Based off of last summer's sweeping reforms, Prince Salman consolidated a lot of power and jailed many of his opponents. Furthermore, Prince Slam already controls three important state pillars Interior, National Guard, and Defense), meaning that his predecessor was getting ready to delegate the job to him and that there will be no need for the Prince to forcefully remove the King from power.

MbS has achieved two critical goals: Oaths of fealty by older members of the family, and a raft of wealth with which to continue to run the kingdom from the wealthy oligarchs within the nation. MbS no longer needs to rush into the role of King at this point. He can choose to ask for it at his leisure, but he is secure in his ability to make strategic decisions unchallenged and to fund those decisions with a newly re-invigorated royal treasury. Predict he will not rush to become King by October because, at this point, he has little to actually gain by becoming official King within this time frame. Salman bA is in no hurry to get off the throne and is also not threatened by the influence MbS has accumulated. No, there will not be a chance of king before October.

With Mohammed bin Salman's new "moderate" and "open Islam" reforms in the Kingdom he will remain in power. "MBS" also has economic plans to help further develop the oil rich country. If he does decide to leave - it will complicated things greater: the conflict in Yemen, and he could still reign but let his son govern as well.

From new interview: https://www.cbsnews.com/news/saudi-crown-prince-talks-to-60-minutes/
Norah O'Donnell: Was it a power grab? Mohammed bin Salman: If I have the power and the king has the power to take action against influential people, then you are already fundamentally strong. These are naïve accusations.

I don't see how it would benefit MBS to ask (or force) his father King Salman to abdicate in his favor, as MBS already has consolidated supreme power with his father's acquiescence.   Leaving his father in place as nominal King gives him some political cover that spares him from some of the power maneuvers from his many rivals (currently on the defensive) that he will eventually face once his father passes away.  The 7% Yes reflects a roughly 7% percent actuarial possibility that Salman, a somewhat frail 85 year old, will pass away in the next 6 months.

I’m surprised consensus has hit 20% on MBS by Oct 1. I definitely think it’s his but does anyone have any info/tea leaves to support what fairly aggressive timing for Saudi? To say nothing if fact, the king usually dies in office versus abdication...
In case the king dies or resigns, yes, most likely MBS.
Shifting toward no and away from someone else because MBS is acting like he's confident in his power and I don't think he is in a hurry to take direct power.

I looked at the life expectancy of an 81 year old male in an actuarial life table. The table I consulted said the man would have a 7% chance of dying, which seems low to me. Life expectancy of someone with dementia in their eighties is about half of normal, so I will raise his chance of dying to 14%. He could abdicate, but the last three kings have died in office. His mental status could complicate things, but he could also continue as a figurehead while MbS rules in practice. All of the arrests and purges seem to be a move to consolidate power to MbS which make him the most likely successor. This makes me think that Salman might consider his death a possibility because he is planning for the future.

MBS is still busy making changes at the top, and it's working for him, see no reason that things change.

However, if any "ill" were to befall the king, MBS has certainly taken plenty of actions to solidify his grip on power locally and he has clearly started a charm campaign on The West. The only way I could see it being someone else is if there is a coup. MBS has been allowed by the current king to take actions that have angered enough people with internal power that can't be dismissed entirely.

Crown Prince MBS has solidified his grip and power and it is unlikely that MBN, or anyone else, would supplant him in the unlikely event that Salman dies.

This was done in the King’s name, but it’s the Crown Prince’s agenda. -- "Signal, GZERO Media" <signal=eurasiagroup.net@mail205.atl121.mcsv.net>

Sadly the format of the opinions rewards luck more than anything else.  Actuarial tables indicate that at 81 you have a 4% chance of death.  Less, as its less than a year; less as its the head of state who receives better than usual care; more as he has several reported health issues. Add to that - will a king abdicate for health or mental reasons prior to death.  Other factors:   Revolt or Coup. The Saudi Prince continues to replace ministers; continues to shake down the wealthy previous princes on trumped up charges of corruption - but he is allowing them to retire comfortably, while recovering assets for the state.  These are the actions of a man capably dealing with the eliminating threats to his rule.   There are no creditable news reports of an organized successor.  Revolt:  Yemen goes badly; iran continues to expand its influence.  But passing the torch to a younger generation is popular; the reforms for women are popular; and rising oil prices will decrease  unrest.  5% chance of a coup (national guard commander; deposed crown prince; or the people fleeced of billions). 
Less, due to a months long windo.
So the actual likehoold is MbS 7.5% due to death or dementia of father.

King Salman abd al Aziz al Saud is 81 years old and his health his a heavily guarded secret. He recently fired his former crown prince in favor of his favorite son and has given Mohammed unchecked and unlimited power of much of the state. While Salman's brothers have lived up to 90, due to his hectic and busy schedule his health is surely to worsen. Mohammed has already implemented major social reform in Saudi Arabia, with such reform it may only be perceived as legitimate once Mohammed has the crown safely in his hands; and in order to make sure his favorite son has no competitors or failures, Salman could be more inclined to abdicate.  https://www.brookings.edu/blog/markaz/2017/06/23/will-saudi-arabias-king-salman-abdicate/ https://www.cnbc.com/2017/10/25/saudi-arabia-promises-a-return-to-moderate-islam.html
Reducing 'No' bucket by 5 to hedge for health of the king.

MBS is in the process of consolidating his power and it is almost a foregone conclusion at this point that he will be declared King at some point. However, there is no reason for him to rush. The internal dynamics of the Saudi royal family are complicated and his moves have already alienated a significant fraction of the power brokers. Due to the explicit support of the Trump administration, it is likely that he will make this announcement before Trump runs for reelection so as not to risk a hostile US administration interfering with this process. In the meantime, he is consolidating his power very successfully without the need to make such an announcement. However, the other factor to consider is that the current King is old and his health is not the best, so MBS will need to make sure he is designated as the official heir before something happens. All in all, I would predict we will see MBS as king before 2020 but it's hard to say when. The 5% I assigned to it being someone else is if the instability results in a coup, but if this happened it would almost certainly result in some kind of civil war.
The current king will likely abdicate once the reaction to the anti-corruption campaign settles down.
He can easily consolidate power and put rivals in prison.  He has the people,  the courts, and the military behind him.

A great deal of instability there...
But the current faction has the upper hand
He is acting like the king

King Salman's health is a closely guarded secret, he's suffering from pre-dementia (which is probably just a euphemism in the political world), and his health is in question.  There have been a number of fired crown princes, however, and the trend of the Saudi Arabian monarchy is to retain power despite incapacity.  Rumors of abdication have been denied; however, this kind of rumoring often contains a grain of truth.  I put weight in rumors like this.   King Salman promised to get rid of corruption before placing Mohammed bin Salman into power, however.  This is currently occurring, which may indicate a time-table.  It is thus plausible that the abdication (or, retirement) is planned within the upcoming year. While I find it unlikely that any king that just began his reign in 2015 will abdicate, his actions seem to be indicative of preparing for his departure. Add to that the health concerns involved, and we have a situation where I can safely place the succession of the current crown prince as a high short-term likelihood.   I think the string of firings of crown princes is over... they are on the path to change, now.  Saudi Denial of Abdication Rumors:

Yes, based off of last summer's sweeping reforms, Prince Salman consolidated a lot of power and jailed many of his opponents. It seemed as if his predecessor was getting ready to delegate the job to him.

The current king is 82 years old, making him significantly older than the average life expectancy for men his age. Whilst he has access to resources that might have increased his lifespan, he likely leads a more decadent lifestyle that has the inverse effect, so this balances out. Therefore, comparing his age to the average life span is a good indicator. The lifespans of the last 3 kings were 69, 84, and 90, so no particular conclusions can be drawn there. The history of kings of Saudi Arabia is also useful insight. The last 3 kings ceased to be king due to death from natural causes, rather than assassination or deposition, making the likely natural lifespan of the king particularly pertinent.   I have left the % of no quite high as a bias towards the status quo. The successor is also left relatively open for now as, though Mohammed bin Salman is the most likely successor, Saudi Arabia has a more ambiguous succession process, so there are a lot of unknowns.
Once more, in the face of uncertainty and unknown factors, I go with continuation of the status quo as most likely - the naive prediction.

The longer he remains, the longer he can consolidate power.  Having just released bin Talal from house arrest at Ritz Carleton in Riyadh, MBS continues to walk the line between keeping power and placating possible enemies.

Muhammad bin Salman's crackdown may be paying off - literally, and in the sense that potential opposition is finding itself having to make an accommodation with him. So if his father dies this year, he will probably become king; after that, we'll see how long he lasts. https://www.wsj.com/articles/billionaire-saudi-prince-al-waleed-is-released-from-detention-1517056497
Started with a judgement of 50/50 based on King Salman staying alive. Scaling back 5% per month as we get closer to 01 October.

Sticking to 50/50. If there’s enough good news (Aramco IPO, slight opening, consistently high oil etc) is it possible father may hand over to son on a high? I know they usually die as leader but many different events lately, starting with Likely nomination of Salman himself

From Wikipedia, the list of kings since ibn Saud: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_rulers_of_Saudi_Arabia#Kings_of_Saudi_Arabia_(1932%E2%80%93present) They are not particularly long-lived, the exception being Abdullah, who died at 90. It's perhaps worth noting that the only king who was a full brother to Salman, King Fahd, died at 84. Salman is 82. Now, it's true that Fahd was reputed to overindulge in a great many things, and had ongoing health problems that were severe, and were known publicly. So it's possible that had Fahd lived a cleaner life, he might have lasted longer. On the other hand, I don't know what vices (if any) Salman has that might shorten his life.  King Salman is rumored to be suffering from dementia (mild or acute, depending on who's telling the story), but under the current circumstances - Prince Muhammad bin Salman consolidating power and eliminating opponents - it is likely that any health problems Salman has will be kept secret, at least to the extent possible. MbS must complete his consolidation while he still has his father's authority to do so. If Salman's health was known to be failing, MbS' opponents might think they could just wait out MbS, and reverse his consolidation before it was finished. I expect that when Salman dies, the announcement will be out of the blue, with no prior warning.
It's about 50/50. If the current king dies, then Mohammed takes over. Saudi kings tend to have long lives though, and King Salman is only 82.

In the old Saudi, would be 100% “no”. With so many under 25’s and desire for change, going with50/50 no/Salman. Women driving. Reopening cinemas. Muted Wahabi response so far. Steady hand required to keep expectations in check (old guard)? But reform speeding up. Floating Aramco and response will be interesting.

I missed this last week, but I think it pertains to this question: https://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/gulf/2018/01/08/King-Salman-directs-Saudi-banks-not-to-deduct-from-royal-gratuity-.html So the Salman/MbS branch of the Saud dynasty is making sure that the military and civil service is to some extent immunized from the economic pain of the reforms. This is not a sign of faith in the succession being uncontested. You don't have to buy off people who will accept your rule as a matter of course. This is interesting too, if confirmed: https://en.dailypakistan.com.pk/world/saudi-billionaire-alwaleed-bin-talal-shifted-to-jail-amid-settlement-talks-claims-arab-media/ The article says that not only has Prince Alwaleed bin Talal been transferred from the Ritz-Carlton to prison, but so have sixty other people held at the Ritz-Carlton. According to multiple sources, the Ritz-Carlton is once again open for business as a hotel; it looks like there are no longer any prisoners at all held there. It's easier to break out of a hotel than it is to break out of a maximum security prison. It's also easier to rescue somebody from a hotel than it is a maximum security prison, and the overall level of control the regime has is much greater. This may be a significant event.  I consider the following quote to be very telling: "Sources also revealed that ‘majority of detainees rejected a compromise submitted by the state to acquire a high proportion of their funds and property in exchange for their release, which is strongly opposed by Walid bin Talal’." Given the circumstances, I regard it as surprising that people being detained by the Saudi government would reject a compromise that allowed them to go free. Unless, of course, they think that there's an element of bluff in the position of the King and the Crown Prince, and that the Crown Prince's status as successor is not completely assured. From the standpoint of the detainees, this could mean that either a) they don't believe that the King will die any time soon, and that their situation may change or at least their detention cannot be extended forever; or b) that the King may die soon, but MbS has antagonized so many crucial elements of Saudi society that his succession will be blocked more or less immediately. The other possibility is that MbS' objective from the very beginning was to eliminate these persons and take the entirety of their fortunes, and the story about their rejecting the compromise is a ruse to make the prisoners seem unreasonable and MbS as having no choice in getting rid of them. But if the story is true, it seems to me that if a man rejects the offer of buying his freedom by handing over a chunk of his fortune, it's because he's willing to gamble that he may soon get his freedom anyway, and with his fortune intact. Either way, things may be moving faster than we think. Some forecasters have cited actuarial statistics about the probability of King Salman dying in a given time frame. This is fine as far as it goes, but we are not talking about a statistical profile of an 82-year-old man. We are talking about *this* 82-year-old man. The question is, then, what are the odds of *him* dying? And the answer is, we don't know. Aside from some rumors about his having Alzheimer's, we have no idea about the state of his health. But one thing we can say with absolute confidence is that Muhammad bin Salman does. I consider it possible that these kinds of changes in the status of MbS' enemies, especially possible rivals within the dynasty, might provide clues to what MbS thinks of his father's chances of living out the year (or until October, as the case may be).

@Resonancia, Thanks for the kind words; I hope your confidence in me isn't misplaced. I think it's improbable - close to impossible - that Salman will abdicate, and as @Khalid points out below, he is statistically unlikely to die in within the time frame of this question. Still, I think  it's worth asking, why is all this happening now? Why is Muhammad bin Salman more or less feverishly clearing the path for his succession? If King Salman is in poor health, that will be a closely kept secret, but MbS will surely know the state of his father's health. Is he acting now because time is running out? MbS has to act while his father is still on the throne, because the authority for his reforms must come from the King. MbS has no mandate on his own to make sweeping changes - and his very position as Crown Prince is in itself a change that might be challenged. Having said all this, I realize that this question may close as a "Yes," but Muhammad bin Salman may nevertheless eventually wind up being removed as King of Saudi Arabia somewhere along the line. It took over two years, for example, to get rid of Richard III of England in 1485. And I think that comparison class is apt: I consider succession in Saudi Arabia to have more in common with dynastic politics in late medieval England than with any modern state. So just as the Wars of the Roses were fought between rival branches of descendants of Edward III, Saudi politics is essentially a dynastic struggle between rival branches of descendants of ibn Saud. It remains to be seen whether MbS' efforts will preempt a violent or protracted struggle, or are just the first moves in one. But there are two things to bear in mind: even what appear to be tiny missteps can wind up being fatal, and alliances in the Middle East are fluid and rarely entail scrupulous ideological or religious alignments. In my opinion, it is not inconceivable, for example, for a rival claimant to MbS to seek - and get - assistance from Iran.

I anchor my analysis around the probability of Salman's mortality.  He is almost 82 years old and while likely well cared for, he is about to become the oldest Saudi monarch ever and there are known health problems in the Saudi Royal Family that have felled other monarchs much earlier in life.   Using American 2014 actuarial tables to get a ballpark forecast, his probability of dying during coming year (were he an average U.S. citizen is approximately 7.2% rising to 7.9% should he make it to his 83rd birthday.   For the first scenario I cost in both familial health problems and discount for his likely high standard of medical care to arrive at a percentage based on a 2014 actuarial chart for U.S. citizens.  I also cost/discount for the possibility of a planned abdication and transition placing MBS on the throne though this move would be unprecedented and thus the costing is not particularly steep. For the second scenario I arrived at a rough projection based on separate possibilities of assassination and coup scenarios.  This ball park figure wraps in the declining prevalence of coups around the globe and the absence of recent coups or critical economic risk factors (HDI ranking has had a strong correlation with coups over the last 10 years) in Saudi Arabia particularly.   I balance this against the delicate situation that is emerging within the Saudi government and royal family (with many unknowns and a great deal of situational opacity) and the steps taken by MBS and the current King to deal with the potential adversaries.  One must also consider that the structure of the Saudi security services presents us with a classic case of "coup proofing" which makes defending against or preventing coups much easier.  There have been assassination attempts and similar breaches of security targeting high-level Saudi royals in recent years and because assassination plots might be viewed as easier to accomplish than an outright coup, I actually apply a steeper discount to coups than I do to assassinations.  One discounting factor that is worth mentioning for assassination scenarios is that in this scenario it would have to involve the simultaneous mortality of both the MBS and the King.  Playing out various sub-scenarios make this seem less likely.  When considering assassinations, the potential number of involved parties grows to include terrorist networks like IS or Al Qaeda and affiliates of Iran/The Iranian Revolutionary Guard. For the third scenario I simply assume, because I used mutual exclusivity as a fundamental principle for the first two forecasts, I simply subtract the first two probabilities from this component of the forecast.

Some interesting discussion here, and since I was pinged, I'd like to make a couple of observations.  First, I don't think MbS is "expendable." Now that he's been turned loose, for King Salman to try to rein him in and say it was all just a terrible mistake with MbS overstepping his bounds will not satisfy the victims of MbS' purge and their allies. The damage to the traditional regime has been done, and the King can't rewind to a time before it happened, even if he decides it's gone too far. I think now that MbS has been given the opportunity to try to consolidate power (for the future) the King can't disassociate himself from it. If MbS' effort was to fail, and he was himself arrested and purged (which I still think could happen), the best Salman could hope for would be a forced abdication for failing to control MbS. Second, Muhammad bin Salman has been a hawk in Yemen, but this in itself is not unprecedented. Saudi Arabia backed insurgents fighting Nasser's Egypt in the 1960s. In that case, the Saudis were afraid of secular nationalists at their back door, and now they're afraid of Iranians. But there was never any reason to think that the Saudis would permit another regional power to control or have a prevailing influence in Yemen. What's unprecedented is not the war as such, but MbS' heavy hand. This was a bad strategy for the Saudis, because it reveals that their military is not terribly effective. Moreover, the reason that 50 years ago the Saudis could restrict themselves to discreet arms shipments to the Yemeni monarchists is that they had the guarantee of U.S. intervention in the event of  a military confrontation with Egypt (Kennedy sent a squadron of planes to Saudi Arabia to demonstrate this). Today, the Saudis are probably a lot less confident of American military support in the event of war. So MbS' more militant stance, while a departure to some extent, has some rational basis given the current context. Finally, it seems to me that letting Muhammad bin Salman arrest other princes, take over assorted government ministries, imprison businessmen for "corruption," etc. is more than just muscle-flexing. MbS may be trying to impress his supporters and overawe his opponents, but I don't think it's quite that easy. Saudi Arabia (up until now, anyway) has been run by means of networks of personal loyalties and affiliations. Everybody is a member of a tribe, a member of an extended family or branch of the Saud family, and the employees of the ministries and civil service are recipients of patronage. You can arrest the guy at the top of the pyramid, but the pyramid doesn't disappear, and you can't get rid of everybody who owes his position, and his loyalty, to your opponents. MbS is banking on loyalty to the other princes not counting when Salman dies. I'm not sure that's a safe bet for MbS, and he may find that the rank-and-file of the ministries, the police, and the military prefer someone else. That's why I give "Someone Else" the same odds as MbS for succeeding to the throne if Salman dies in 2018.

I spoke with a Saudi expert who had lived there and keeps tabs on the politics. He said that if MBS was going to be king, he'd have done it before he cracked down on the other princes for 'corruption'. His take was the crackdown was a flex of muscles to let the leadership know they've picked the right guy.  He also said to take note of MBS pushing forth the Yemeni war, as no other Saud has been a war hawk since old man Saud who founded Saudi Arabia. Between the hawk tendencies and the corruption crackdown, MBS is putting the family on notice that he intends to be a strong king.  On the other hand, the current king is known to have some form of dementia (not sure if that is public knowledge) and that leads me to bump up my estimate by 3% as it changes morality tables and the family to find a strong replacement when the time comes.  On the other hand, MBS is far younger than any other known king, which is a significant break with tradition. That hints that he's going to be 'seasoned' a while.  Overall, if we had a time machine to replay the next 10 months 100 times, I think there'd be a new king 13 out of 100 times.

I thought this was an interesting read, thanks to @Prognosticating-Beek for posting in http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/650073 and for @September for re-posting it. It seems like most of the options don't have Moh. bin Salman becoming king directly.  It also seems likely to me that MbS is rushing to boldly try out new policies as a test of political strength and new wave of political/social politics to prove whether he is able to reposition KSA in as a more central leader in the Middle East and put it in better economic and political power and advance certain limited social reforms without things imploding.  I guess I don't see his MbS's activity as such a clear sign of plans to pass off leadership.  It seems more like a leash to test out the waters and see if his brand of political and social leadership is something people will salute if they run it up the flagpole.  He is a rather EXPENDABLE resource in this way, I think, and something that KSA needs right now.   They have growing young population, many of them with education (thanks to the previous King Abdullah's education projects to improve universities in KSA and send students abroad) but not always with jobs.  The economy is still largely dependent on oil even though there have been efforts to diversify over the past decade or more.  The social pressure within is increasingly complicated because there is still a very high value on traditional culture and religious practices even though there are equally strong pressures to modernize in some ways without dividing social unity.  And the situation in the Middle East, especially now with Iran powering up, require some urgent change or a loss of perceived, if not real, power and influence.  I know a lot of people are are leaning toward Mohammed bin Salman becoming king pretty quickly, and I know there have been rumors in the press (everyone likes a good story).  But the averages here in favor of MbS seem surprisingly high (45%), and if anyone has any thoughts about why they think it's likely that Mohammed bin Salman might be very likely to be named king before October (or might not be), I'd love to hear any of your thoughts!  I haven't seen as many comments or news threads in this question and the predictions seem to be all over the place.  Anyone care to share what they think? I am pivoting this totally. First I went for 99% for crown prince mohammed bin salman, but reading through a bunch of articles I can say that it would be a poor strategical choice for Saudi-Arabia. In addition I believe the current king is wise enough not to make that decision during his lifetime, perhaps after his death the prince might rise in power.
The path has been paved for the crown prince MBS to take the throne, it is merely a matter of when. I personally think it won't be so soon.

King Salman is 80, he has still time to live. He will not abdicate the throne before naming a deputy crown prince, so there is still time. The recent power grab by MBS seems to have worked, and there would be no reason to change the current ruling situation for a while atleast.
King Abdullah has only reigned for two years and he is still younger than the two prior kings. I think he may have a few more years in power and he will use that time to better train MBS.
Kings of Saudi Arabia like to their 90s, and the son is already the de facto ruler. Worthless words mean nothing. Power grows from the barrel of the gun, not some farcical mandate of the masses.

It is reported that the King was called by Putin today. Maybe the call was actually answered by someone else, but assuming it was the King who spoke to Putin he seems to be alive and able to hold meetings. In the past Saudi Arabia has replaced Kings who were mad or bad, but Salman does not seem to be either, so unless he dies he is probably going to stay King for now. Mohammed bin Salman is very divisive and I am sure many Saudis in positions of power do not want him as the next King, but they are probably very divided about who they do want, so the probability is that he will be the next King, but its far from certain.
